qas.question: A 5th-century building in Huldah is believed to be what?
What does the mosaic at Huldah contain?
What language are the inscriptions on the mosaic at Huldah?
The synagogue located in Bet She'an had what kind of symbols depicted in its mosaic?
The masters who built the floor in the synagogue at Bet She'an also constructed what other mosaic?

answers.text: the floor of the Beit Alfa synagogue

context: A 5th-century building in Huldah may be <a0_0>a Samaritan synagogue<a0_0/>. Its mosaic floor contains <a1_0>typical Jewish symbols<a1_0/> (menorah, lulav, etrog) but the inscriptions are <a2_0>Greek<a2_0/>. Another Samaritan synagogue with a mosaic floor was located in Bet She'an (excavated in 1960). The floor had only decorative motifs and an aedicule (shrine) with <a3_0>cultic<a3_0/> symbols. The ban on human or animal images was more strictly observed by the Samaritans than their Jewish neighbours in the same town (see above). The mosaic was laid by the same masters who made <a4_0>the floor of the Beit Alfa synagogue<a4_0/>. One of the inscriptions was written in Samaritan script.
